docs.text: ConfIDent-schema metamodel version: 1.7.0 version: 0.0.1 This is a schema for the ConfIDent project that describes the necessary metadata requirements of academic events and event series. Classes AcademicField - An academic field is the scientific subject of the planned process according to some controlled vocabulary or thesaurus and as such requires the scheme URI. City ConfIDentRecords - This is a container to be able to bundle academic event and series data in one data file (e.g. YAML or JSON). Contributor Attendee Moderator Organizer CommitteeMember CommitteeChair ContactPerson Presenter KeynoteSpeaker Reviewer Sponsor Country Date - A container for the start and end date, the date status as well as the duration of a planned process. Deadline - A container for event deadlines. EventFormatSpecification - An academic event format specification is a plan specification that classifies a planned gathering of people in an academic context according to some sociocultural format, which provides implicit and explicit details on how this gathing is to be carried out by its participants in terms of achieving certain objectives, fulfiling certain conditions and performing certain actions. It thus concretizes the expectations of the contributers of an academic event. While the explicit details are often provied as concrete parts (e.g. deadline or attendance fee specifications), the implicit details depend on the semantics encoded in the words used for the classification of academic events (e.g. "conference" or "workshop"). Depending on the sociocultural background these classifications can overlap or vary to a certain degree. ExternalIdentifier DblpId - The identifier of an academic event or series in dblp. GndId - The identifier of a thing (item) in the German National authority file. TibkatId - The identifier of a publication in the TIB catalog. WikiCfpId - The identifier of an academic event or series in WikiCFP. WikidataId - The identifier of a thing (item) in Wikidata. Location Metric PlannedProcess - Abstract base class for academic events and event series. AcademicEvent - An academic event is part of the established instruments of science communication as a format for conveying the latest scientific outputs. It is defined by the meeting of researchers at a specific time and place (virtual or physical) and with a specific thematic focus to present, hear and discuss these outputs. In contrast to other forms of events, academic events should primarily serve the exchange of results and methods of scientific research and their didactic mediation. Furthermore, a significant participation of scientific organizations in the realization of an academic event is constitutive for this type of event; for example, to distinguish it from events in which researchers mainly act as external experts or with a purely legitimising function. AcademicEventSeries - An academic event series describes the set of academic events which take place on a regular basis and thus have an established common identity. This identity is constituted, for example, through institutional continuity in the hosting of a series (e.g. by a specialised society), thematic focuses and/or a common label under which a series is defined (particularly name and acronym). Nevertheless, it is possible that each of these criteria may change over time. ProcessName ProcessRelation Region Venue Mixins NamedThing SchemaBasedThing Slots AcademicEventSeries➞series_of - The relation used to provide the events belonging to an AcademicEventSeries. AcademicEvent➞at_location - The location of the academic event. AcademicEvent➞deadlines - A property to deadline_type is mandatory. AcademicEvent➞event_format - The sociocultural event format which is specified by the organizers, e.g. conference. Possible values are defined in the EventFormat enum, which uses the named individuals defined in AEON. AcademicEvent➞event_mode - The event mode describes whether the event is a physical, virtual or hybrid event. AcademicEvent➞in_series - The relation used to provide the series of which an AcademicEvent is a part. AcademicEvent➞ordinal - The ordnial number of an academic event within its series. AcademicEvent➞related_to academic_fields - A property used to describe the scientific subject of the planned process according to some controlled vocabulary or thesaurus. Requires the as subproperties the name and if possible the URL of the identifiying scheme. ConfIDentRecords➞events - An attribute that specifies a list of academic events within this container. ConfIDentRecords➞series - An attribute that specifies a list of academic event series within this container. contact - The contact person of an academic event or event series. ContactPerson➞email - The email address of the contact person. ContactPerson➞telephone - The telephone number of the contact person. Date➞duration - The duration of an event or series which gets automatically derived, if a stard_date and end_date have been provided. Date➞end_date - Similar to start_date but only for the end of an academic event or event series. Date➞event_status Date➞start_date - The start date of an academic event or event series. Wheres the latter will in reality most likely be the start date of the first event of this series, unless there is some other source from which it is possible to derive the date of the inception of the series. dates - A property refering to a date container that holds the start date, end date and status of a planned process. Deadline➞deadline_date - The date of a deadline. Deadline➞deadline_other - This property can be used to specify another kind of deadline, if this type of deadline is not within the allowed values of DeadlineType. doi - A digital object identifier (DOI) according to https://doi.org/. dpbl_id EventFormatSpecification➞other_format EventFormatSpecification➞specified_as external_id - a property to provide the internal id of a schema entity gnd_id id - a property to provide the internal id of a schema entity ContactPerson➞id EventFormatSpecification➞id landing_page - The website to which a persistent identifier is linking and which contains all the metadata about an academic event or series. ➞city ➞country ➞lattitude ➞longitude ➞meeting_url ➞region ➞venue ➞int_value ➞other_metric ➞rate_value ➞str_value ➞truth_value metrics name PlannedProcess➞name - This property is used to provide a name of the academic event or series, which itself has further properties to specify its type (e.g. official name, acronym, etc). aliases - A property to be used to provide alternative names as strings. ProcessName➞acronym - The official acronym of an academic event or series. ProcessName➞former_name - The former official name of an academic event or series. Usually this will only be needed in case an academic event series has undergone a name change. ProcessName➞official_name - The official name of an academic event or series. ProcessName➞translated_name - A translation of the official name to be used in different language contexts. organizers outputs - The published works that are related to the academic event or event series, such as proceedings and video recordings of talks. schema_base_uri - The base URI of a schema. DblpId➞schema_base_uri GndId➞schema_base_uri TibkatId➞schema_base_uri WikiCfpId➞schema_base_uri WikidataId➞schema_base_uri schema_name DblpId➞schema_name GndId➞schema_name TibkatId➞schema_name WikiCfpId➞schema_name WikidataId➞schema_name sponsors summary topics type - an abstract property used to specify the type of a thing Deadline➞type - The type of deadline. Metric➞type ProcessRelation➞type value ➞address website AcademicEvent➞website - the official website of an academic event wikicfp_id wikidata_id Enums DeadlineType EventFormat - The permissible values defined in this enum class represent the most common minimal event format specifications. For event formats that are not in this list, you can use "other" and provide the label of this other event format as strind using other_format . EventMode EventStatus MetricType RelationType Subsets Types Built in Bool Decimal ElementIdentifier NCName NodeIdentifier URI URIorCURIE XSDDate XSDDateTime XSDTime float int str Defined Boolean ( Bool ) - A binary (true or false) value Date ( XSDDate ) - a date (year, month and day) in an idealized calendar Datetime ( XSDDateTime ) - The combination of a date and time Decimal ( Decimal ) - A real number with arbitrary precision that conforms to the xsd:decimal specification Double ( float ) - A real number that conforms to the xsd:double specification Float ( float ) - A real number that conforms to the xsd:float specification Integer ( int ) - An integer Ncname ( NCName ) - Prefix part of CURIE Nodeidentifier ( NodeIdentifier ) - A URI, CURIE or BNODE that represents a node in a model. Objectidentifier ( ElementIdentifier ) - A URI or CURIE that represents an object in the model. String ( str ) - A character string Time ( XSDTime ) - A time object represents a (local) time of day, independent of any particular day Uri ( URI ) - a complete URI Uriorcurie ( URIorCURIE ) - a URI or a CURIE

docs.text: Enum: EventFormat The permissible values defined in this enum class represent the most common minimal event format specifications. For event formats that are not in this list, you can use "other" and provide the label of this other event format as strind using other_format . URI: confident:EventFormat Other properties Permissible Values Text Description Meaning Other Information colloquium A colloquium is an academic meeting that usually lasts only a few hours and serves to discuss a specific topic. Colloquia are usually part of the academic exchange in everyday university life with only one speaker, but can also take place on special occasions (anniversaries, start or end of the lecture phase, etc.) and can have more than one speaker. conference A conference is an academic event that lasts up to several days and serves as a forum for presentations on a specific topic or subject area. In addition to subject-specific conferences, there are also interdisciplinary conferences which allow both a broader focus and more specific questions on a particular (academic) problem. Conferences often have a highly formalized structure of parallel, clearly defined sessions with several short presentations and plenary sessions with invited (keynote) speakers who are considered multipliers in their (research) field. Ideally, the selection of the speakers and their contributions is subject to a review process. {'is_a': 'EventFormatSpecification'} congress A congress is a certain type of conference which is characterised by a larger number of participants (often several hundred) and is oftentimes organised jointly by large, established (e.g. specialised societies) and/or several institutions. Congresses have a broader thematic focus than simple conferences, take place in certain cycles, but can still target an exclusive group of participants (e.g. representatives of a single discipline). session A session is a clearly defined part of a academic event in which a small number of speakers (usually 2-5) focus on a specific topic. A session is usually formally accompanied by a session chair, who assumes the function of a moderator. poster session A poster session is a session at which poster papers are presented. talk A talk is a central part of a larger academic event, at which a specific topic is being presented in a rather short way. keynote speech A keynote speech is a special talk that has the function to set the underlying tone and summarize the core message or most important revelation of the academic event at which it is given. event track An academic event that, as a part of a larger academic event, has the function to group even smaller parts of the academic event, like sessions and talks, according to a shared theme or topic. It usually has dedicated chairs and program committees. forum An academic event whose sociocultural format is determined in an academic event type specification that classifies the academic event as a forum. hackathon A hackathon is a gathering of software developers with the goal to develop software collaboratively in a short timeframe. seminar A seminar can serve as a term for older conference series, but in current usage the term mainly describes a specific teaching format that serves to develop content and provides space for discussion. Participation from the audience is usually encouraged. symposium A symposium is a specific type of conference with a narrower thematic focus, with fewer participants and of shorter duration. The degree of structuring lies between a classic conference and a workshop, allows more discussion than the larger conference, but is usually more formalized than the workshop. tutorial An academic event that has the function to educate the audience on a certain topic. A tutorial is often realized as an academic event talk or academic event session. workshop Workshops are smaller academic events that serve to exchange information on a specific topic or problem. They usually last one or two days and offer space for discussion and the development of content and solutions. Group work is often part of the event concept. other This value is to be used if the event format cannot be represented using one of the other permissible values defined in the EventFormat enum. If this value is chosen the use of other_format is mandatory.
docs.title: Enum: EventFormat

docs.text: Class: EventFormatSpecification An academic event format specification is a plan specification that classifies a planned gathering of people in an academic context according to some sociocultural format, which provides implicit and explicit details on how this gathing is to be carried out by its participants in terms of achieving certain objectives, fulfiling certain conditions and performing certain actions. It thus concretizes the expectations of the contributers of an academic event. While the explicit details are often provied as concrete parts (e.g. deadline or attendance fee specifications), the implicit details depend on the semantics encoded in the words used for the classification of academic events (e.g. "conference" or "workshop"). Depending on the sociocultural background these classifications can overlap or vary to a certain degree. docs.text: Class: PlannedProcess Abstract base class for academic events and event series. URI: confident:PlannedProcess Uses Mixin mixin: NamedThing Children AcademicEvent - An academic event is part of the established instruments of science communication as a format for conveying the latest scientific outputs. It is defined by the meeting of researchers at a specific time and place (virtual or physical) and with a specific thematic focus to present, hear and discuss these outputs. In contrast to other forms of events, academic events should primarily serve the exchange of results and methods of scientific research and their didactic mediation. Furthermore, a significant participation of scientific organizations in the realization of an academic event is constitutive for this type of event; for example, to distinguish it from events in which researchers mainly act as external experts or with a purely legitimising function. AcademicEventSeries - An academic event series describes the set of academic events which take place on a regular basis and thus have an established common identity. This identity is constituted, for example, through institutional continuity in the hosting of a series (e.g. by a specialised society), thematic focuses and/or a common label under which a series is defined (particularly name and acronym). Nevertheless, it is possible that each of these criteria may change over time. Referenced by Class Attributes Own doi 0..1 Description: A digital object identifier (DOI) according to https://doi.org/. Range: Uriorcurie landing_page 0..1 Description: The website to which a persistent identifier is linking and which contains all the metadata about an academic event or series. Range: Uriorcurie landing_page 0..1 Description: The website to which a persistent identifier is linking and which contains all the metadata about an academic event or series. Range: Uriorcurie dates 0..1 Description: A property refering to a date container that holds the start date, end date and status of a planned process. Range: Date organizers 0..* Range: Organizer contact 0..1 Description: The contact person of an academic event or event series. docs.text: Abstract base class for academic events and event series. URI: confident:PlannedProcess
docs.title: Class: PlannedProcess

docs.text: AcademicEvent - An academic event is part of the established instruments of science communication as a format for conveying the latest scientific outputs. It is defined by the meeting of researchers at a specific time and place (virtual or physical) and with a specific thematic focus to present, hear and discuss these outputs. In contrast to other forms of events, academic events should primarily serve the exchange of results and methods of scientific research and their didactic mediation. Furthermore, a significant participation of scientific organizations in the realization of an academic event is constitutive for this type of event; for example, to distinguish it from events in which researchers mainly act as external experts or with a purely legitimising function. AcademicEventSeries - An academic event series describes the set of academic events which take place on a regular basis and thus have an established common identity. This identity is constituted, for example, through institutional continuity in the hosting of a series (e.g. by a specialised society), thematic focuses and/or a common label under which a series is defined (particularly name and acronym). Nevertheless, it is possible that each of these criteria may change over time.

docs.text: Introduction ConfIDent is a service platform for academic events. It aims to make the descriptive metadata on conferences and other formats of academic events permanently accessible in a high quality, through automated processes and scientific data curation. ConfIDent as a sustainable service addresses researchers who search for and publish information on academic events, as well as universities, information infrastructure institutions, specialised societies, publishers and funding agencies. The ConfIDent Metadata Schema is a list of core metadata entities and properties chosen for an accurate and consistent identification of an academic event or academic event series. The goal of the present schema is an alignment with DataCite’s Metadata Schema v4.4 , in order to be able to register via DataCite a DOI for an academic event or an academic event series. Besides the DataCite Schema v4.4 we have used the following as reference for the present schema draft: * Crossref Schema v4.5.0 (draft) , * Scientific Events Ontology (SEO) * schema.org/Event and schema.org/EventSeries This schema representation is based on this draft .

The ConfIDent Metadata Schema is a list of core metadata entities and properties chosen for an accurate and consistent identification of an academic event or academic event series. The goal of the present schema is an alignment with DataCite’s Metadata Schema v4.4 , in order to be able to register via DataCite a DOI for an academic event or an academic event series. Besides the DataCite Schema v4.4 we have used the following as reference for the present schema draft: * Crossref Schema v4.5.0 (draft) , * Scientific Events Ontology (SEO) * schema.org/Event and schema.org/EventSeries This schema representation is based on this draft .
